Award.AwardTitle: Europa's role in the Jupiter system
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to determine limits for the rate of atmospheric escape from the moon Europa into Jupiter's plasma sheet. The research will constrain important properties of Europa's atmosphere, including the presence of H2O vented from a subsurface ocean. To accomplish its goals, the project will model the Europa plasma sheet to determine plasma diffusion probabilities, lifetimes and mass loading rates.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. The work could inform future decisions on whether a dedicated space mission to Europa is warranted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observations of Europa and the surrounding environment have been analyzed using atomic and molecular emission models to extract physical properties from EUV/FUV spectra. The main spectrograph data source is the Cassini UVIS experiment. The model architecture originates entirely from work at USC and SET. In a number of cases there are no comparable models.

The analysis of the Europa atmosphere observations in this program concludes the atmosphere is composed primarily of atomic oxygen. This is in conflict with earlier publications that assume an O2 atmosphere with a density 100 times larger. The implication of this result is that the presence of a subsurface source of H2O is not supported. The report of an observation of an H2O plume in an earlier publication raised the speculation that the subsurface ocean was in contact with the surface. This in turn would suggest the possibility of the existence of life forms. The results from the present research does not support the inferred rate of mass loading of the magnetosphere inferred by the earlier work, and shows that the contribution to the surrounding magnetosphere plasma is minor compared to the outflow from Io. The plasma at the Europa orbit is found to be dominated by ion species originating in the Io plasma torus. Acontribution of oxgygen from Europa is inferred. The plasma density at the Europa orbit is 20 times below the density in the Io plasma torus.

The broader impact of the work lies in the inference for future spacecraft exploration of the Jupiter system. Spectrograph sensitivity of future instruments should be a factor of 5 greater than the Cassini UVIS system. Spectral resolution should be on the scale of the FUSE system.


Last Modified: 09/20/2019
Modified by: Donald Shemansky
